section.title: Injecting Mappers
section.para: The most interesting feature of MyBatis 3 is mappers. MyBatis-Spring lets you inject mappers on your service beans. When using mappers there is no need to use MyBatis API (selectOne, selectList, insert, update...) you simply call your mappers as you have always called your DAOs.

This is the way you create a mapper: <bean id="userMapper3" class="org.mybatis.spring.MapperFactoryBean"> <property name="sqlSessionFactory" ref="sqlSessionFactory" /> <property name="mapperInterface" value="sample.UserMapper" /> </bean> When using mappers you don't need to set up mapper list on the mybatis-config.xml file because mappers are able to register themselves to MyBatis during startup. If you don't want you mappers to self-register set the addToConfig property to false.

You inject mappers directy on your business/service objets in the same way you usually inject DAOs: <bean id="fooService3" class="sample.FooServiceImpl"> <property name="userMapper" ref="userMapper3" /> </bean> With injected mappers your code will have no MyBatis-Spring dependencies and no MyBatis dependencies either.
